title: Erdős Problem #346: Complete Sequences and the Golden Ratio
description: If a lacunary sequence is strongly complete but fragile (removing any infinite subset destroys completeness), must a_{n+1}/a_n → φ?

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Graham (1980) studied sequences that are strongly complete (removing finitely many terms preserves completeness) but fragile (removing infinitely many destroys it). Graham (1964) showed F_n − (−1)^n is such a sequence. The golden ratio φ = (1+√5)/2 appears as the threshold: if a_{n+1}/a_n > φ, fragility is automatic.
overview.problemStatement: If A is lacunary, strongly complete, and fragile, must lim a_{n+1}/a_n = φ?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines subset sums, completeness, strong completeness, and fragility. Graham's example is axiomatised. The golden ratio threshold and the main conjecture are stated, along with the existence of irregular (non-lacunary) counterexamples.
keyInsights: Strong completeness: finitely many removals preserve completeness
Fragility: infinitely many removals destroy completeness
Graham's sequence F_n − (−1)^n satisfies both properties
If a_{n+1}/a_n > φ always, fragility is automatic
The conjecture applies only to lacunary sequences; irregular ones exist

sections.title: Complete Sequences
sections.summary: Subset sums and completeness: all large integers are representable.

sections.title: Strong Completeness and Fragility
sections.summary: A is strongly complete if finite removals preserve completeness; fragile if infinite removals destroy it.

sections.title: Lacunary Sequences
sections.summary: Lacunary: a_{n+1}/a_n ≥ 1 + ε. The golden ratio φ ≈ 1.618.

sections.title: Graham's Example
sections.summary: Graham (1964): F_n − (−1)^n is strongly complete and fragile.

sections.title: Golden Ratio Threshold
sections.summary: If a_{n+1}/a_n > φ for all n, fragility is automatic.

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: Erdős Problem 346: lacunary + strongly complete + fragile implies ratio → φ.

conclusion.summary: The formalization captures Erdős Problem 346, asking whether the golden ratio is the unique limit ratio for lacunary sequences that are both strongly complete and fragile.
conclusion.implications: A positive answer would show that Fibonacci-like growth is the unique regime balancing representational richness and fragility, connecting complete sequences to the golden ratio.
openQuestions: Must the ratio tend to φ for lacunary sequences?
Can the lacunarity hypothesis be weakened?
